content: Has anyone managed to do better than 36 bytes in python for the Shortest mode?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Solved with brute force very easily

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Approved the contribution.
As you can solve it without any specific functions nor optimization, so ideal for a clash of code.

General
* It's not fair if Python has a specific function to answer the problem while other programming languages do not. Having said that, please at least let players who don't know `pow` in Python or players of other programming languages have a chance to pass the clash by simple brute-forcing. Hence, I suggest to reduce the upper bound of [[m]] to make that possible.

Input
* Please delete "(positive or not)" (not sure what you are trying to say here).

Game modes
* Suggest to disable Reverse mode as it may be too difficult to guess the requirement.

Cases
* Each pair of test and validator should be similar but *not the same*. For this clash, please revise the cases so that the magnitude of the input is similar for each pair (to achieve similarity).

* Please balance the magnitude of input among the cases (currently you have either very small inputs or very large inputs - very extreme). So, together with the above point, you may try:

Test 1 and Validator 1: 1 ≤ x, m ≤ 9
Test 2 and Validator 2: 10 ≤ x, m ≤ 99
Test 3 and Validator 3: 100 ≤ x, m ≤ 999
Test 4 and Validator 4: 1000 ≤ x, m ≤ 9999
And so on if you want more than 4 pairs of cases.

Thanks.

Done!

General
* Reduced the upper bound of [[m]] from 10^9 to 10^4 to make brute-force approaches feasible for all players, regardless of the language they use.

Input
* Deleted ambiguous "(positive or not)"

Game modes
* Disabled Reverse mode as it may be too difficult to guess the requirement.

Cases
* Updated test cases and validators to balance the magnitude of input among the cases.
